resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

pitrou opened a new pull request #11062:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11062


   Also use a more reasonable default "max_length" value for binary-like and list-like types.
   
   WARNING: this may change some benchmark numbers due to the "max_length" change.


--

pitrou commented on pull request #11062:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11062#issuecomment-911324362


   Ok, this confirms that the `arrow-compute-scalar-if-else-benchmark` and `arrow-compute-scalar-compare-benchmark` benchmarks with string data will not be comparable before and after this PR. This is also, IMHO, for the better: the previous random generation, with a max string length of 1024, produced data that was less realistic (most string data in Arrow is probably very short). @lidavidm @dianaclarke  What do you think?
   


--

lidavidm commented on pull request #11062:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11062#issuecomment-911589609


   I think it's ok. As you said, the long strings before were perhaps unrealistic. They would also have biased the benchmarks towards measuring the speed of memcpy instead of the overhead of the kernel operations.


--

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

fields.description: It seems the two variants of {{RandomArrayGenerator::ArrayOf}} (one taking a Field, the other taking a Datatype) use completely different implementations, for no obvious reason. They should be reconciled so that the most powerful implementation is used.
